title: Harnessing The Future Of Digital And Smart Manufacturing Of Medical Devices - Med Device Online
summary: Digital and smart manufacturing are essential to maximize efficiency, improve productivity, and meet the needs of customers in the medical device manufacturing industry. Digitalization and smart manufacturing can improve end-user safety, expedite the expansion of a company’s product portfolio, and satisfy regulatory requirements. Smart manufacturing enhances digital manufacturing processes even further through the use of manufacturing execution systems (MESs), which connect live production information between multiple vendors and locations and integrate with a company’s existing equipment and business applications.
green_innovation: TRUE, the article promotes using AI, machine learning, and manufacturing execution systems (MESs) to improve efficiency, reduce errors, and increase regulatory compliance.
business_innovation: TRUE, the article promotes using digital and smart manufacturing, PLM systems, and MESs to improve efficiency, productivity, and regulatory compliance.
green_product: FALSE, the article does not describe a specific green product.
green_process: TRUE, the article promotes using smart manufacturing and MESs to improve efficiency, productivity, and regulatory compliance.

title: Medtech Innovation Needs a Digital Upgrade | BCG - BCG
summary: Medical device innovation can no longer focus solely on isolated product launches; instead, companies should adopt a platform approach focused on continuous product updates and improvements. To succeed, medtech firms need to innovate more closely with end users, redesign innovation processes for speed, and develop the necessary talent base.

title: How businesses can close China's AI talent gap - McKinsey
summary: The demand for AI talent in China is growing rapidly, and the country is facing a shortage of qualified workers. Companies in China need to upskill their existing workers and diversify their talent sources in order to fill the talent gap. Some companies are also outsourcing work to other countries in order to access needed talent.
greenwashing: The article does not provide enough information to determine whether the described product or process innovation is an example of greenwashing.

title: Viral Safety With ICH Q5A Revision 2 - BioProcess Insider
summary: The article discusses the revised International Council for Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Pharmaceuticals for Human Use (ICH) guideline Q5A(R2), which provides guidance on the testing and evaluation of viral safety of biotechnological products derived from cell lines of human or animal origin. The revised guideline includes key changes, such as new sections on viral vectors and related products, continuous manufacturing, and the use of prior knowledge (PrK) for modular validation and resin-reuse studies, and new molecular analytical methods, particularly next-generation sequencing (NGS), to reflect improvements to current scientific knowledge. The revised guideline is likely to support the implementation of advances in viral safety based on recent published scientific advances.
green_innovation: TRUE. The article describes an important new revision of an ICH guideline that covers viral safety evaluation of biotechnological products, which supports green innovation by allowing for reduced animal testing.
business_innovation: TRUE. title: IDM Approach Continues to Strengthen ST's Semiconductor Leadership - EE Times India
summary: The company STMicroelectronics is investing heavily in its SiC business, which could help support sustainability through power-efficient solutions and technologies.   Alongside the SiC investments, ST is also building GaN capacities and capabilities.   ST is strengthening its manufacturing capabilities and building internal capacities through investments in automation and digitalization, but customer demand continues to outpace supply.
